title: 109_hr3558
content: The Act may be cited as the "Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Amendments Act of 2005". The Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program, authorized by the Flood Control Act of 1944, aimed to promote economic development. The Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project, a key part of the program, impacted the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe by flooding their land and causing economic and cultural damage. Congress has provided compensation to affected Indian tribes. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe suffered loss of homes and communities due to the Pick-Sloan projects. Congress enacted the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act to provide compensation, but it did not include additional compensation for tribal members who lost land due to the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe suffered losses due to the Pick-Sloan projects. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund aims to compensate tribal members who lost land because of the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe seeks equitable compensation for losses incurred from the Pick-Sloan projects. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe seeks fair compensation for the Oahe Dam and Reservation project, where the United States acquired land from the Tribe and member landowners. Amendments aim to ensure adequate compensation for the acquired land. Amendments to the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act define terms like "member landowner" and "power program" related to land acquisition for the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund is amended to receive 25 percent of the amount deposited into the Treasury from the power program for a specific period starting in 2004. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund receives 25% of the total amount deposited into the Treasury from the power program for a specific period, with details on the calculation of the amount described. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund receives interest and earnings based on the Lehman Government Bond Index. Amendments include changes in the fiscal year start date and additional compensation for member landowners. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation allows for additional compensation to member landowners for land acquired by the United States for the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Secretary of the Interior must provide records to assist the Tribe in processing claims of heirs of member landowners. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act allows for additional compensation to member landowners for land acquired by the United States for the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. Section 105 is amended to include eligibility for any member landowner to access certain programs and services.
